You have no confidence in political parties, the press, or the civil service, and you are skeptical of organizations like the World Bank, the United Nations, and the World Health Organization. However, you do have quite a lot of confidence in your country’s government and military, which you believe should prioritize maintaining order and ensuring national security. You would be willing to fight for your country if war were to come, and you place a high importance on a stable economy and strong defense forces for the future.

You are moderately satisfied with your life these days, rating your satisfaction as a 9 on a scale of 1-10. While you are content overall, you are not without concerns. You worry a great deal about terrorist attacks, crime, and the potential for war involving your country. You feel insecure at times and have avoided going out at night for safety reasons, but you do not feel unsafe in your home. You trust your neighborhood completely, and you are not aware of any incidents of street violence, robberies, or drug sales in your area.

Your political views place you at the center of the political spectrum. You believe in the importance of having a government that upholds democracy and protects individual rights, particularly civil rights. You also believe that a high level of economic growth should be one of the country’s top priorities. You do not believe that the government should prioritize the needs of immigrants over those of your own citizens, and you think immigration increases unemployment and social conflict. You are against the idea of a woman earning more than her husband, believing it could cause problems. You disagree with the view that work is a duty towards society, and you think that it is a bad thing if less importance is placed on work in people's lives.

While you are not actively involved in political protests, you do believe in the importance of fair elections. You think that votes are counted fairly often, although you are skeptical about the fairness of opposition candidates running for office. You consider the media, especially TV news, to often favor the governing party and believe that all journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You do not trust the press or the courts, and you do not feel that your personal life is frequently interfered with by the police or military.

Your views on immigration are complex. While you believe that immigration fills important job vacancies, you think that the government should strictly limit the number of foreign workers allowed to come into the country. You are not in favor of immigration leading to increased cultural diversity, and you agree that it contributes to higher crime rates. However, you also agree that immigration can offer people from poor countries a better life and provides asylum to political refugees.

You are not highly engaged in global issues and do not have confidence in international organizations such as the United Nations or the International Criminal Court. However, you feel that international organizations should prioritize being effective over being democratic. Your stance on environmental issues is also skeptical, as you have no confidence in environmental organizations.

Your views on moral issues are relatively conservative. You strongly believe that violence against others and stealing property are never justified. You also do not believe that prostitution, euthanasia, or homosexuality are ever justified. You have a very low tolerance for corruption, believing that all business executives, civil service providers, and journalists are involved in corruption. At the same time, you think that competition is good, and you strongly believe that men make better political leaders than women.

On a personal level, you neither consider yourself to be close to your continent nor do you feel a strong attachment to it. Your views on science and technology are mixed. While you believe that science and technology make life healthier and more comfortable, you do not think that the world is particularly better or worse off because of it. You moderately believe that we sometimes struggle to decide on the right moral rules and that people should take more responsibility for themselves, with limited emphasis on government support. You also feel that people can be trusted in general, though you do not trust strangers or people from different nationalities or religions.

You believe that having a strong leader who can govern without parliament and elections could be a good thing for your country. This shows your preference for stability and strong governance, even at the cost of democratic processes. In this sense, you value security more than freedom and think that making people's incomes equal is an essential part of a functioning democracy.

Lastly, your health is fair, and you consider leisure time to be very important in your life. You are not involved in any sports or recreational organizations and do not mind having neighbors with various lifestyle differences, such as heavy drinkers, people of different races or religions, or those with AIDS. However, you would not feel comfortable with drug addicts or homosexuals as neighbors.
9117:
You were born in 1971, and your father was born in this country, while your mother was born in country 76. Family is an important aspect of your life, and you are married with eight children. You live in a household with ten people, including yourself. Although you are not the chief wage earner in your household, you are actively involved in a labor union and you take your role as a father seriously. Your spouse has never had a job, and while you feel that work is rather important in your life, your family has sometimes struggled with financial hardships. In the last 12 months, your family occasionally went without enough food to eat and sometimes went without a cash income.

In terms of political beliefs, you strongly align with the right end of the spectrum, placing your views at position 10, which is the furthest right. You have no membership in any political party, nor in any political organization, but you consider political discussions with friends important. While you are somewhat interested in politics, you are not highly engaged. You believe that votes are counted fairly very often in your country’s elections, and you trust election officials to be fair. You feel satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country today, and you believe it is absolutely essential for democracy to have free elections, where people can choose their leaders.

You consider democracy an essential element of governance, and while you are open to some forms of governance, you believe there should be no political parties or elections under religious law, and a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections could also be a good system. Nevertheless, you are strongly against government surveillance, and you believe that the government should not have the right to collect information about citizens without their knowledge. You believe that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy.

Your beliefs around immigration are mixed. You feel it would be good to limit immigration to prevent people from coming to work, yet at the same time, you agree that immigration can offer people from poor countries a better life. You feel that immigrants could have a bad impact on the development of your country, and you believe that immigration might lead to social conflict, although you're unsure. You also find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies or strengthens cultural diversity.

Religion plays a significant role in your life as you belong to the Roman Catholic denomination. You believe in God and place God at the center of your existence, with religion being very important to you. You attend religious services on special holy days and pray several times a week. You firmly believe in heaven and hell, and you agree that religious authorities should interpret laws within a democratic system. You strongly disagree with the idea that science should take precedence over religion, and you completely agree that we depend too much on science and not enough on faith in today’s world.

Despite your religious convictions, you are open-minded toward those with different beliefs. You trust people of another religion completely, and you do not mind having people of other religions, races, or nationalities as neighbors. However, you would not want homosexuals or people with HIV as neighbors, and you strongly oppose homosexuality and casual sex, believing that such behaviors are never justified.

You have a strong sense of responsibility, especially toward your children. You believe that good manners and hard work are essential qualities for children to learn, but you do not consider independence or imagination important. You also place a high importance on teaching children to feel a sense of responsibility and to do good by others.

You view the role of science and technology in the world as overwhelmingly positive. You completely agree that science and technology have made life healthier, easier, and more comfortable. You also believe that the world is better off because of them, although you feel there might be too much emphasis on their importance. You do not mind the development of technology in general but feel that the development of competition in the economy is harmful.

Regarding your community, you are satisfied with your neighborhood, as crime is not prevalent. You have not been a victim of crime in the last year, and neither has your family. You do not feel unsafe in your neighborhood and have not avoided going out at night for security reasons. However, you are worried about the impact of terrorist attacks and potential wars. You also believe that street violence and drug sales are more frequent in other neighborhoods.

You are somewhat interested in politics but do not engage in any online political activities, nor would you encourage others to do so. You have signed a petition before and might join a strike or boycott if the cause is right. However, you would never attend a peaceful demonstration, and political violence is something you find unacceptable in any form. You place great importance on having honest elections and believe that making sure elections are free and fair is essential for democracy.

You strongly believe in individual freedom and rights, but you also consider security more important than freedom when forced to make a choice. You would fight for your country in the event of war, although you hope that such a situation will not arise. While you support a democratic system, you also believe that certain aspects of democracy, like strong defense forces, are vital for the country’s future.

In your opinion, religion should guide people's actions more than secular laws, and you consider people who accept bribes, commit violence, or act immorally as never justified. You believe that a person should never be forced to give up their private life to government surveillance or interference.

You are a firm believer in a system where people should obey their rulers, as long as the leaders have been chosen through free elections. You trust the police, courts, and civil service and have confidence in major companies, the press, and international organizations like the United Nations. However, you have little faith in the International Monetary Fund and believe that many business executives are involved in corruption.

You feel very secure in your life and are quite happy overall, considering your well-being and the stability of your home and community. Despite the struggles you face in your personal life, you remain proud of your country's nationality and feel a strong attachment to it, although not particularly to your region or district. Your confidence in your country’s governance system is high, and you are satisfied with the democratic process, although you do not believe that democracy is perfect.

In the context of your personal beliefs, you do not mind having unmarried couples or drug addicts as neighbors, but you strongly oppose same-sex couples as parents. You feel a sense of responsibility toward your country and your family, placing high importance on their well-being, while striving to maintain strong personal values and beliefs regarding religion, democracy, and family.
92350:
You were born in 1967, and you’ve lived in your country all your life. You consider yourself very proud of your nationality, and you feel a strong connection to your town, village, or city. You were raised in a home where neither you nor your family ever went without enough food, shelter, or a safe environment. This has shaped a deep appreciation for security and stability in your life.

At 50 years old, you are married and have three children. You and your spouse belong to the professional and technical group, which means your household has a stable income. However, you describe yourself as part of the working class, and your family's financial situation has been more or less steady, with your family just getting by during the past year. You do not belong to any political party or union, nor are you a member of any humanitarian, charitable, professional, or educational organizations. Despite this, you hold strong views on what is important for the development of both your country and family.

Your religious beliefs are central to your life; you are a Roman Catholic, and God is very important to you. Religion, particularly following its norms and ceremonies, is a guiding principle for you. Though you are not very active in attending services, you are actively involved in a religious organization. You believe in heaven and hell, and consider religion to be crucial to understanding right and wrong. Despite these deep convictions, you don’t believe religious faith is an important quality for children to learn.

You believe that family plays an essential role in life, and that having good manners and a sense of responsibility are qualities children should learn. You think that hard work is the most important quality for children to develop, and that it leads to a better life in the long run. In fact, you strongly believe that hard work usually brings a better life, and this has influenced how you approach work in your own life. Work is rather important to you, and although you are employed full-time (over 30 hours a week), you place a strong emphasis on personal responsibility over state aid. Your job is crucial for your family, but you also believe leisure time should hold some value.

Your views on politics are largely shaped by a moderate concern for both government and individual responsibility, but you lean more toward government responsibility. You are somewhat interested in politics, but you prefer not to align yourself with any political group. You feel that a democratic political system is not ideal for your country, as you would rather have strong leaders who don't have to deal with parliament and elections. You do believe in the importance of honest elections and maintaining order in the nation. However, you are not very satisfied with how the political system functions today. 

You have a considerable amount of confidence in international organizations like NATO, the World Bank, the United Nations, and the civil service. However, you do not have much trust in the press, television, or banks. You find that the information you receive from daily sources, such as emails, mobile phone updates, TV, and radio news, plays a large part in your understanding of the world. Still, you feel that the press and the courts are often corrupted and do not inspire much confidence. 

On social issues, you maintain fairly conservative views. You believe political violence and terrorism are never justified, and you are strongly opposed to any form of stealing, including claiming government benefits to which one is not entitled. You also think that individuals should never beat children or spouses, and that adults should never justify cheating on taxes, avoiding fares, or engaging in prostitution. While you do believe in helping political refugees, you also agree that immigration can lead to social conflict, increase unemployment, and fill important job vacancies. You believe that immigration provides asylum to political refugees as long as there are jobs available, but should be limited when jobs are scarce.

You are concerned about the risks of a terrorist attack and worried about war involving your country, which you would be willing to fight for, should it come to that. You also feel the impact of competition and believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies, not necessarily to do good to others. You are neutral about science’s role in everyday life but prefer a practical approach over technological overdependence. 

You trust people you meet for the first time somewhat and feel it’s necessary to be very careful in dealing with people. You have no specific views on people from other countries working in your country, but you believe the government should prioritize local citizens when jobs are scarce and that immigration can contribute to both cultural diversity and crime. You do not mind having neighbors of different races, religions, or sexual orientations, and you would not feel uncomfortable living next to unmarried couples, people with AIDS, or homosexuals. However, you wouldn’t like heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people who speak different languages as neighbors.

Despite your more conservative stances, you’re open to certain reforms to improve society. You are skeptical of the media and large institutions, which you feel are often corrupt, but you have a great deal of confidence in your government, the armed forces, and the police. You also feel strongly that private ownership should increase and that the fight against crime should be a top priority.

You are generally satisfied with your life overall and enjoy the peace and security of your neighborhood. You have never been the victim of crime, and you have not had to carry money for security reasons. However, you feel somewhat insecure these days and would prefer a balance between freedom and security, with a slightly greater emphasis on security. 

In your personal and family life, you do not consider work to be a duty to society or feel that there is an obligation to have children. You also find that your children’s education and well-being are important, but you do not place much emphasis on religious faith as part of their upbringing.

Ultimately, you would describe yourself as generally happy, moderately satisfied with your country’s democratic system, and confident that hard work and a strong defense are necessary for the future. You look forward to a more stable, secure, and well-ordered society.
6007:
You were born in 1958 in this country, and you take great pride in your nationality. Your family is important to you, and you live in a household of four people, including yourself. You have two children, and family has always played a central role in your life. You strongly believe that it is a duty towards society to have children and that feeling a responsibility for others is an important quality for children to learn. You are very proud of your country's history, but you also feel it is important to be cautious when dealing with people, believing that trust must be earned over time.

Religion plays a significant role in your life. You belong to the Muslim denomination and attend religious services more than once a week. Your belief in God is central to your existence, and you are deeply committed to religious teachings. You strongly agree that the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies, rather than simply doing good for others. You believe that science and religion should be in harmony, with religion always being the right choice when they conflict. Your faith is important, and you pray several times a day. Your belief in heaven and hell is unwavering, and you consider your religion to be the only acceptable one.

In terms of your political views, you place yourself moderately left on the political spectrum, holding strong opinions about the role of government and democracy. You feel that a democratic political system is the best way to govern this country and believe that voting and free elections are essential to democracy. However, you also believe that the government should have some control over people's lives, such as monitoring communications and enforcing strict surveillance measures in public areas. While you believe in the importance of democratic rights, you also feel that the state should ensure the equality of incomes and provide support for the less fortunate. 

You have a lot of confidence in international organizations like NATO, the World Bank, the World Health Organization, and the International Monetary Fund, but you do not trust the media or the press. You feel that journalists and media outlets are often involved in corruption, and you do not trust the political coverage they provide. You also believe that votes are rarely counted fairly in your country's elections and that the public is often given limited choices during elections. While you are not a member of any political party, humanitarian organization, or other types of social groups, you feel that the government should prioritize the well-being of the citizens and the protection of human rights.

Although you believe in the importance of work, you are also cautious when it comes to issues of immigration. You feel that immigration increases unemployment and that the government should limit the number of foreigners allowed to work in the country. You also believe that immigration can lead to social conflict, though you see immigrants as having a good impact on your country's development. However, you are firm in your stance that immigrants should not be given priority over native citizens when it comes to employment.

Your views on marriage and relationships are traditional. You believe that women should have equal opportunities to run for public office but also feel that certain roles, such as caring for children, are better suited for women. You strongly disagree with the idea that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples, and you do not want to live near people who are homosexual, have AIDS, or are heavy drinkers. You also think that casual sex and prostitution are never justified. Regarding your own marriage, your spouse has never had a job, though they completed primary education, and you find it very important to make your parents proud. 

You are somewhat skeptical of government intervention in daily life, although you believe that the government should have the right to monitor emails, public communications, and video surveillance in public spaces. You believe that the state should focus on defense, with the most important goal being to ensure the country has a strong defense force over the next ten years. You also see the fight against crime as a significant priority and are very concerned about potential wars involving your country, as well as terrorist attacks.

Despite your concerns about external threats, you feel secure in your current living environment, as there is no history of crime in your neighborhood. You avoid carrying much money for security reasons, and street violence or robberies are not common in your area. Your neighborhood does not have issues with racism, and you generally trust the people around you, though you are very cautious about who you trust. You also do not feel that political violence is justified, though you do not discuss political matters with friends.

In terms of your economic standing, you consider yourself to be part of the lower middle class. You are retired and receiving a pension, and you feel largely satisfied with your life, believing that your standard of living is better than your parents' at your current age. You have saved money in the past year, and your family rarely went without a safe shelter or cash income. You believe that people should take more responsibility for their own lives, with limited support from the government. However, you also think that work is important and that it is a duty towards society. You do not mind living next to people of different religions or languages but are more resistant to living near people of different races or sexual orientations.

You are quite conservative in your views on education and child-rearing. You consider good manners and a sense of responsibility to be essential qualities for children to learn. You do not consider imagination, religious faith, or hard work to be particularly important qualities for children. Your mother had no formal education or only early childhood education, and your father never had a job. You strongly agree that a man should not beat his wife, though you believe that divorce is rarely justified and that a wife earning more than her husband is likely to cause problems.

Your stance on national issues shows that you are quite invested in maintaining a strong, democratic society. You feel that there is a great deal of respect for individual rights in your country, and while you would not like to have unmarried couples living together as neighbors, you are not against having people of different religions living nearby. However, you strongly believe that the government should be governed by religious law, with no political parties or elections, and that religious authorities should interpret laws. You believe that people obeying their rulers is absolutely essential for a functioning democracy, and you do not want a system where decisions are made by experts rather than the government.

Lastly, while you feel somewhat close to your continent and region, your true attachment lies to your country and its governance. You believe that the most important goal for the next ten years is to ensure national security, and you are a strong believer in the role of the government in protecting the country’s values and interests.
25204:
You were born in this country in 1966 and are 52 years old. You were raised in a family where religion played a significant role in your life. Your mother was born here, and your father, originally from country 818, worked as an unskilled laborer. Both of your parents emphasized hard work, religious faith, and the importance of strong family values, which have deeply influenced your own life choices. You are currently married and live in a household of four people, including yourself and your spouse, who works in the clerical field. You and your family have not faced financial hardship in the past year; you have never gone without enough food, shelter, or a steady income. You live in a community where street violence and drug sales occur quite frequently, but despite these challenges, you feel very secure in your daily life. 

As a devout Muslim, religion is a core part of who you are. You attend religious services more than once a week and believe that God is paramount in your life. You view the basic meaning of religion as following religious norms and ceremonies rather than focusing on doing good for others. Your faith strongly shapes your worldview, and you have a deep belief in life after death, heaven, and hell. This spiritual devotion influences your views on other aspects of life, such as your belief that religion is right when it conflicts with science. You strongly agree that the duty of adult children is to care for their parents long-term, and you believe in the importance of passing on religious faith to your children. Family is incredibly important to you, and you work hard to make your parents proud, which has been one of your life's main goals.

Your political views are complex. You do not belong to any political party, nor do you discuss political matters with your friends. You neither agree nor disagree on whether people receiving state aid for unemployment is an essential feature of democracy, but you do think it would be beneficial for your country to have a democratic political system. Although you are not highly confident in institutions like the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the World Bank, or the United Nations, you still hold some level of faith in the civil service and environmental organizations. You consider democratic elections to be moderately fair, although you are concerned that opposition candidates are often prevented from running. In your view, it is crucial to have honest elections, as you believe they are an essential characteristic of democracy. You have no confidence in the press or major companies, and you do not trust journalists to provide fair coverage of elections. You do not rely on email, radio news, or friends for information, but instead obtain information mainly through TV news, even though you do not have very much confidence in television.

While you do believe that freedom and security are both important, you would choose security over freedom, especially in the face of potential threats. You view work as a crucial part of life and consider it a duty towards society. You believe that hard work is essential for a better life and that a stable economy should be the country’s most important goal. You strongly agree that work should come first, even if it means sacrificing leisure time. You also believe that when jobs are scarce, priority should be given to native workers over immigrants. On the issue of immigration, you hold a mixed stance: while you agree that immigration fills important job vacancies and strengthens cultural diversity, you also believe it leads to social conflict and increases the crime rate. You think the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to work in the country and that immigration fills important job vacancies. You do not believe that immigrants have a particularly good impact on the country's development, though you somewhat believe they offer people from poor countries a better life.

You view democracy as important, though with some reservations. You do not feel strongly about whether voters are often threatened with violence during elections, but you consider having the opportunity to vote in free elections to be of significant importance. You also believe that the people should have the power to choose their leaders through free and fair elections, and you believe the political system in your country is moderately democratic. Although you do not support the idea of a political system governed solely by religious law, you do feel that a system without political parties or elections could have some merits. You strongly believe that the state's role is to ensure that everyone is provided for, with minimal emphasis on individual responsibility, and you moderately believe that government intervention is necessary for ensuring economic equality. 

You also care deeply about societal stability and respect for human rights, but you have a limited view of how these concepts play out in real life. You feel that your country offers respect for individual human rights, but you believe that there is still some room for improvement. You view the fight against crime as the second most important goal for the country, after maintaining a strong defense. Your opinions on issues like terrorism, political violence, and violence against others are extremely firm, as you believe they are never justified. You believe that people should obey their rulers and that civil rights protecting people from state oppression are somewhat essential for democracy.

You describe yourself as being in the upper middle class, with an income in the seventh highest group in your country. You are the primary wage earner in your household, and you and your family saved money during the past year. Your family has never felt unsafe from crime, and no one has been a victim of crime in the past year. Your standard of living is better than your parents' was when they were your age. While you agree that the government should be responsible for taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor, you also somewhat support private ownership over government ownership of businesses and industries. 

You are generally satisfied with your life, though you feel neutral about whether people have trouble deciding which moral rules to follow today. You are somewhat indifferent about the role of science in everyday life, though you believe it is important for people to stay informed about science. You have confidence in the civil service, banks, and charitable organizations, but you are not a member of any professional or humanitarian groups. You are not a member of any political, educational, or cultural organizations, and you do not believe in petitioning or joining strikes or boycotts. 

In summary, you are a devout, middle-aged Muslim man with a strong sense of family and a deep belief in religious values. While you are critical of many political institutions and systems, you hold firm beliefs about the importance of work, security, and the preservation of your country's cultural identity. Although you trust people in your immediate circle, you tend to be cautious in your dealings with others. Your views on immigration, democracy, and social roles reflect a strong belief in preserving societal norms and structures.
29872:
You were born in this country in 1941 and, at 76 years old, you are now retired, living with your spouse and one child in a small household of three people. Your spouse belongs to the semi-skilled worker group, completing primary education. Your father, who was born in this country, worked as an unskilled laborer, while your mother, who was born in this country, had only early childhood education. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower class and are not very satisfied with your life these days, rating your happiness as very low.

Family is central to your life. You are very proud of your country's nationality and consider it very important to make your parents proud. You strongly believe that having children is a duty towards society and that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You also strongly agree that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. You are a deeply religious person, belonging to the Orthodox denomination, and you attend religious services once a week. God is very important in your life, and you believe in heaven, hell, and life after death. You strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. Your religious faith is something you consider vital for children to learn, alongside good manners and hard work.

In terms of your political views, you place yourself in the center, on position 5 of the left-right scale. You are not a member of any political party, but you would vote for Party 2 in a national election if it were held tomorrow. You do not trust the press or television, but you have some confidence in institutions like the government, parliament, civil service, and courts. You are moderately confident in the functioning of your country's democracy, rating it 5 out of 10, and believe the government should take responsibility for ensuring everyone is provided for, though you do not trust people you meet for the first time very much. You believe that the democratic system is important and that living in a country governed democratically is high on your list of priorities. You have strong opinions about the role of democracy and freedom, believing that democracy should include regular elections, civil rights, and government responsibility for taxation and subsidies to the poor. However, you feel that the political system is not functioning optimally in your country today and rate your satisfaction with it as neutral (5 out of 10).

You have a complicated view of immigration. While you believe that immigration should be limited and that the government should control the number of foreigners coming into the country, you also think immigration has a positive impact on your country's development. However, you feel that it can increase social conflict, raise unemployment, and increase the crime rate. You feel that immigrants should not be prioritized over citizens when jobs are scarce, but you also agree that immigration offers people from poorer countries a better life.

You are skeptical of foreign influence, especially when it comes to international organizations. While you have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations and the World Health Organization, you place a higher priority on effectiveness over democracy in international organizations, rating it 5 out of 10. You are not particularly concerned about terrorism or war, but you are worried about a potential conflict involving your country. You also do not worry much about a terrorist attack, although you are cautious about security, having avoided carrying much money and going out at night in recent times.

You have a strong belief in personal responsibility and see work as a duty towards society, with work always coming first for you, even if it means sacrificing leisure time. You strongly agree that people who don't work are lazy and that hard work brings a better life, albeit with limited attribution to luck. However, you believe that people should not cheat on taxes or take government benefits to which they are not entitled, and that stealing is never justified. You believe in a stable economy, with economic growth being a primary goal for the country. You also feel that the government should not monitor people's private information, such as e-mails, and should not have the right to collect data without their knowledge.

When it comes to social issues, you are generally conservative. You strongly believe that behaviors like prostitution, casual sex, and stealing are never justified, and you also reject ideas like homosexuality or sex before marriage, holding rigid views on moral issues. You do not mind living next to unmarried couples or people of a different race or religion, but you strongly believe that your religion is the only acceptable one. You are very clear in your belief that violence, including violence against women or children, is never justified, and that votes in elections should be counted fairly and without intimidation.

Your community experiences vary. You live in a neighborhood where robberies occur quite frequently, but you feel somewhat secure, and crime is not a significant concern for your family. You are not close to your continent, but you feel close to your town or city. While you are not the chief wage earner in your household and occasionally felt unsafe or lacked a cash income, your family has never gone without enough food or shelter in the past year.

In terms of societal changes, you believe that the country should focus on improving its cities and countryside, and fighting rising prices should be a priority. You also believe that more emphasis should be placed on developing technology, although you are not particularly interested in scientific knowledge in your daily life. You strongly agree that scientific progress should not overshadow religious faith, and that we depend too much on science in today's society.

You are generally cautious and find it hard to trust others. You do not feel very close to your neighbors or others you meet, and you avoid discussing political matters with friends. Your confidence in major institutions like the press, banks, and television is minimal, and you believe journalists rarely provide fair coverage of elections. However, you place a lot of trust in charitable organizations, the armed forces, and environmental groups.

Overall, your worldview is shaped by a deep belief in the importance of religion, family, and hard work. You are skeptical of change, especially when it involves foreign influence or a shift away from traditional values. You believe the government should prioritize security and stability, and you feel that social issues should be governed by clear moral standards.
86674:
You were born in 1981 in this country, and you take quite a bit of pride in your nationality. Your background reflects a blend of both personal beliefs and social realities, shaping the way you view the world today.

Your father was born in country 156, making him an immigrant to this country. Your mother, however, was born in this country and completed primary education. Family plays a significant role in your life, and you live with your parents in a household of three people, including yourself. Despite the importance of family, you’re not particularly inclined to think that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You live with the belief that your family has never gone without enough food to eat, shelter, or cash income over the last year, though you feel your family just got by.

At 37 years old, you’re currently single and without children. You are employed full-time, working 30 hours or more each week. Work is important to you, but you also agree that it would be a good thing if less importance was placed on work in your life, as leisure time is a priority for you. Despite this, you do not see work as a duty toward society. You strongly disagree with the notion that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time.

You belong to the fourth lowest income group in your country and describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class, but you maintain a sense of caution when it comes to money, avoiding carrying much for security reasons. Financial security, however, remains a concern for you. Your family has rarely felt unsafe from crime in the last 12 months, though you have personally been a victim of crime. You feel quite secure these days overall.

Your education includes a Bachelor's degree or equivalent, and you consider imagination and independence as important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not consider hard work or good manners as crucial qualities for children to learn. You also place little importance on religious faith in a child’s upbringing. You neither believe in heaven nor hell, though you do believe in God, who holds a somewhat important place in your life. Despite this, you do not attend religious services regularly.

Politically, you lean heavily to the left, as indicated by your position at level 1 on the political spectrum. You feel that living in a country governed democratically is absolutely important, and you strongly believe in the essential nature of people choosing their leaders in free elections. You hold a great deal of confidence in institutions like NATO, the World Bank, the United Nations, the International Criminal Court, and the International Monetary Fund. On the other hand, your confidence in local organizations like the press, television, the civil service, and universities is minimal. You have a strong distrust of the media, believing journalists are often involved in corruption and that TV news frequently favors the governing party.

You’re not particularly active in politics, although you are a member of a political party and a professional association. You might occasionally discuss political matters with your friends and have signed electronic petitions. While you consider yourself somewhat interested in politics, you feel somewhat dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country. You also tend to disagree with the idea that women make better political leaders than men, as you believe that men and women are equal in this respect.

Your stance on social issues is a mix of open-mindedness and pragmatic concern. You strongly believe in freedom of choice when it comes to issues like divorce, casual sex, and euthanasia, all of which you consider almost always justified. You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of different religions, races, or sexual orientations as neighbors, though you would not want heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors. You also strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you would not like to live in a system governed by religious law.

When it comes to immigration, you agree that it can fill important job vacancies and offer asylum to political refugees, but you also believe it leads to social conflict and increases unemployment. While you feel that immigration strengthens cultural diversity, you also think that immigration can have a negative impact on the development of your country. You believe the government should allow people to immigrate as long as there are jobs available, but you feel that employers should prioritize people from your country over immigrants when jobs are scarce. You are not worried much about terrorism or the threat of a terrorist attack, although you are somewhat concerned about a war involving your country.

You have a deep conviction about democratic values, and you believe that political violence is never justified, seeing it as an unacceptable means of political expression. Similarly, you do not believe in terrorism as a political or religious tool, but you also believe that people who don’t work eventually turn lazy. You feel that adults have a duty to care for their parents, but you are neither a member of a women’s group nor any humanitarian or charitable organizations.

In your daily life, you obtain information from your mobile phone, email, and the Internet frequently, though you do not trust people of another religion or nationality very much. You also feel that most people can be trusted in general. Your confidence in the police, courts, and armed forces is fairly high, though you do not have much faith in the press, government, or civil service.

While you moderately believe that science and technology are making lives easier and more comfortable, you are neutral about whether society depends too much on science and not enough on faith. Similarly, you feel that science is neither wholly beneficial nor detrimental to the world. You believe that progress should be made toward a society where ideas matter more than money, and you consider cultural diversity more important than technological development.

You strongly believe that sexual harassment, violence, and corruption should never be justified, and you do not condone stealing property, accepting bribes, or cheating on taxes. When it comes to rights, you strongly believe in equality, especially for women. You do not think that men have more right to a job than women when employment is scarce, and you believe that women having the same rights as men is essential for a democratic society.

Your overall health is fair, and you are somewhat dissatisfied with your life overall. You are moderately dissatisfied with how things are going in your country, but you feel a deep sense of responsibility to make your society better through gradual reforms.

In terms of your general views on democracy, you place a lot of importance on individual rights and freedom, emphasizing that the government should not interfere excessively in private lives or monitor people without their consent. You strongly believe that the government should take more responsibility for ensuring everyone is provided for, though with minimal focus on individual responsibility. You also believe that making sure the country has strong defense forces should be the second most important goal over the next decade, while focusing on fighting rising prices as a national priority.

In your personal life, you remain cautious and pragmatic, balancing your personal and political beliefs with a desire for a fairer, more democratic society. You feel that politics, family, and individual rights are central to shaping your future and the future of your country.
10459:
You were born in 1960 in your home country, and you take great pride in being part of this nation. Over the years, you’ve established a solid foundation for your life and family. You are married, and your spouse works in a service-oriented profession, which adds an interesting dynamic to your household. Together, you live with your two children in a two-person household, where family remains a central and important part of your life. 

Your parents have played a significant role in shaping your worldview. Your father was born in the same country as you, and worked in the professional and technical field, perhaps influencing your approach to work and success. Your mother, also born in the country, completed lower secondary education, which is likely indicative of the values and standards that you were raised with. Your family never went without enough food or shelter in the last 12 months, and while financial matters are important, you belong to the sixth-highest income group in the country and have saved money over the past year. This stability has helped you build a confident outlook on life. 

In your everyday life, you rely on various sources of information to stay informed. You obtain information from email and mobile phone daily, while you also keep up with news through TV, radio, and newspapers. You value the press and television as sources of information, though you have some reservations about how often they favor the governing party. Despite this, you believe that votes are counted fairly in your country’s elections, and you trust in the integrity of election officials. You are moderately satisfied with the political system in your country, rating it at a 7 on a scale of 1-10, and believe that elections provide a genuine choice for voters.

Though you are not involved in any political party, you have a strong sense of civic duty. You consider work an important part of your life, but you also believe in the importance of leisure and a balanced lifestyle. You feel strongly about the importance of democracy and oppose a system governed by religious law or by a strong leader who bypasses elections. You also believe that freedom is more important than equality, although you have a moderate belief in the importance of government intervention in areas such as the economy and social issues. You moderately agree that incomes should be more equal, and feel that a high level of economic growth is essential for the country.

Your views on immigration reflect a balance of caution and openness. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies and strengthens cultural diversity, but you believe there should be strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to come into the country. You feel that immigration could lead to social conflict and negatively impact the development of the country. Despite this, you agree that immigration offers people from poor countries a better life, though you feel conflicted about whether it increases unemployment or crime. 

Your religious beliefs are moderate in importance in your life, as you are a Roman Catholic but attend services less than once a year. You pray several times a week and believe in God, as well as in the concepts of heaven and hell. While you value the role religion plays in your life, you are not overly concerned with religious norms, and you strongly disagree that religion should always take precedence over science. You also believe in the importance of moral behavior but reject any justification for violence or abuse, including beating children or a spouse. 

Your confidence in international organizations such as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the United Nations, and the World Health Organization is fairly high, although you do not trust the International Criminal Court or the World Bank much. You do not believe in heavy government surveillance or video surveillance in public areas, reflecting your belief in personal freedoms. You are also wary of government interference in private life and oppose the idea of experts making decisions for the country without the involvement of elected officials.

You have a somewhat cautious approach to relationships and trust. You do not trust people you meet for the first time very much and believe that it is essential to be careful in dealing with others. Despite this, you value friends and maintain a close-knit social circle. Your family is a priority, and you encourage your children to learn qualities like good manners and a sense of responsibility. You believe that respect for individual human rights is fairly common in your country today, and you are moderately satisfied with your life overall. 

You also have strong opinions on issues related to justice and ethics. For instance, you believe that theft, bribery, and cheating on taxes are never justified, and you think that corruption is a significant issue among business executives. You oppose violence in all forms and have a firm stance against political violence, believing it is almost never justified. You think it is essential to have a fair and honest electoral process, and that seeing more people participate in decision-making processes at work and in their communities should be a priority for the country. You believe that having children is a societal duty and that women should have equal opportunities in public office. 

Your approach to life is marked by balance, with a slight emphasis on hard work over luck or connections. You consider economic stability and growth, security, and maintaining order to be the most important goals for your country. At the same time, you place moderate value on the role of science and technology in improving lives and believe in making informed choices based on evidence and reason. 

In terms of your personal and social life, you maintain a fairly neutral stance on issues like homosexuality, agreeing that homosexual couples are just as capable of being good parents as other couples. You do not mind having neighbors who belong to different religions, races, or speak different languages. You believe in equal rights for men and women, rejecting the notion that men make better business executives or political leaders. However, you feel that it is important for a man to take responsibility for his family and that work is both a duty and a source of personal fulfillment. 

Ultimately, you believe society should be gradually improved through reforms, not radical changes, and that there is still room for progress in achieving a truly democratic and fair society. You are moderately confident in institutions like banks, courts, and universities, but have reservations about larger corporations and government institutions. Despite your cautiousness and somewhat reserved demeanor, you maintain an optimistic view of the world and your place in it, valuing personal integrity, democracy, and the well-being of your family.
37931:
You were born in 1975, and you have spent your life in your home country, where you remain proud of your nationality. Your father was born in this country, and your mother, although born in a different country, completed lower secondary education. Your family has always been somewhat stable financially, though you consider yourself to be of the lower middle class. Over the years, you have built your life around a set of firm beliefs and principles.

Your family structure is central to your life. You live in a household of eight people, which includes your own parents and spouse, with whom you share one child. Your spouse, despite having completed upper secondary education, has never held a job. You believe strongly in the importance of family and have a close connection to your immediate community, feeling a sense of belonging to your village, town, and region. While you are not the primary breadwinner in your household, you are employed part-time, working less than 30 hours per week. You have been careful with your finances, having at times relied on savings and borrowing money. You also avoid carrying much cash for security reasons.

Regarding religion, you belong to the Hindu denomination, and while you believe in God, religion plays a minor role in your life. You only attend religious services on special holy days and feel that the primary meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than adhering strictly to religious norms and ceremonies. Nonetheless, you strongly agree that it is a duty to have children for the benefit of society. You hold your religious beliefs firmly, and God is quite important to you, ranking at an 8 on a scale of 1-10. 

You are not particularly politically active, though you occasionally engage in discussions about politics with friends. Your political views lean firmly to the right, and you place yourself at position 10 on the political spectrum. You do not belong to any political party, nor are you a member of any political or humanitarian organizations. You are, however, very firm in your beliefs regarding democracy, agreeing that the government should have the right to monitor all e-mails and communications exchanged on the Internet, as well as the ability to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. You also believe that the army taking over when the government is incompetent is a necessary characteristic of democracy, and you hold strong views on maintaining civil rights to protect individuals from state oppression.

You are skeptical of international organizations like NATO, the World Bank, and the IMF, feeling that they are not trustworthy. You do not trust the press or media and have little faith in television as a source of information, despite relying on TV news daily. You also do not obtain information from radio news but do regularly access information from your mobile phone and the Internet. You tend to avoid gathering information from email, preferring other sources.

Regarding your views on immigration, you believe that the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners allowed to enter the country for work. While you recognize that immigration can fill important job vacancies, you feel that when jobs are scarce, priority should be given to people from your country over immigrants. You are neutral on whether immigration increases crime but do agree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees. You do not believe that immigration strengthens cultural diversity and feel that immigrants have neither a good nor bad impact on the development of the country.

In terms of social values, you hold firm beliefs about work and responsibility. Work is extremely important to you, and you strongly believe that it should always come first, even at the expense of leisure. You also think it is a duty toward society to contribute through hard work. You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy, and you place a strong emphasis on good manners and a sense of responsibility as important qualities for children to learn. You believe that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and you strongly agree that men make better political leaders than women.

When it comes to ethics and morality, you are very firm in your convictions. You strongly disagree with justifications for activities such as casual sex, stealing property, or cheating on taxes. You believe that violence against other people, including terrorism and political violence, is never justified. You also reject the idea of divorce, casual sex, and homosexual relationships, strongly asserting that these are never justified. On the other hand, you believe that some forms of parental discipline, such as occasional corporal punishment, are justified.

Despite your strong views on certain topics, you are somewhat pragmatic in others. You somewhat believe that competition is beneficial but have concerns about its harmful effects. Similarly, you hold moderate views on science and technology, believing that they do not necessarily make our lives better but are not entirely detrimental either. You also believe that technological development should be emphasized but are cautious about its overall impact on society.

You value your personal security, avoiding going out at night when possible, and having experienced no major crime in your neighborhood. You live in an area where street violence is frequent, but robberies and drug sales are rare. You believe that the fight against crime is of utmost importance, and you feel secure in your daily life, despite the prevalence of alcohol consumption in the streets of your neighborhood. You trust your neighborhood and feel that the police and military are not intrusive in your private life.

On a more personal note, you place your own happiness and well-being in a somewhat neutral stance, rating your life satisfaction at a 5 on a scale of 1-10, and stating that you are not very happy overall. You consider yourself to be in poor health, though you feel secure in your current situation. The greatest source of pride for you is your role as a parent and your desire to make your parents proud, which has been one of your main life goals.

In conclusion, you believe in a system where democracy thrives, but with a strong emphasis on security, responsibility, and personal freedom. While you are not particularly interested in politics, you feel strongly about the importance of strong defense, maintaining national priorities, and ensuring that the country’s economy grows. You also prioritize family and community, with a clear sense of your role within both. Though you hold firm conservative views, you are pragmatic and thoughtful in your approach to the complexities of society, work, and life.
49824:
You were born in 1966 in your home country, and you take great pride in being of your nationality. You consider your connection to your country and region to be very close, and you are proud of your heritage. Your family is an essential part of your life, and you live with three members in your household. You are married and have four children. You feel that family is a critical part of who you are, and you strongly believe that one of your primary life goals has been to make your parents proud.

Religion plays an important role in your life as well. You belong to the Orthodox denomination and attend religious services more than once a week. You believe in God and place a lot of importance on religious norms and ceremonies, as you feel they guide your life. You believe in both heaven and hell and have a strong sense of religious duty. For you, religion is about following the rules and norms, not just doing good for others. Despite this, you disagree with the idea that religion is always right when it conflicts with science. 

You are male and 52 years old. Your father was born in your country and worked as an unskilled laborer, while your mother was born in a different country, although she completed primary education. You describe yourself as belonging to the working class, though you also consider yourself to be part of the middle income group in your country. You live in a neighborhood where street violence, robberies, and other crime are not common, and you feel quite secure these days.

Your professional life is essential to you. You are employed full-time, working at least 30 hours a week. You are the chief wage earner in your household and have a somewhat strong work ethic. You believe that work is a duty toward society and that it should come first, even if it means sacrificing leisure time. At the same time, you feel that a system where work is given too much importance in life could be detrimental. You also somewhat agree that there should be greater incentives for individual effort, with some support for income equality. 

Your spouse works in the sales group and has completed lower secondary education. You don't trust people you meet for the first time very much, nor do you trust people of another nationality or religion. However, you are somewhat accepting of having people of different races, religions, or nationalities as neighbors. In fact, you do not mind having people who speak different languages, have AIDS, or are homosexuals as neighbors. Although you have concerns about certain societal issues, such as immigration and its potential impact on unemployment and crime rates, you also recognize the importance of immigration in filling job vacancies and offering asylum to political refugees.

Politically, you feel moderately dissatisfied with the current state of your country’s system and government. You do not belong to any political party, nor do you engage much in political discourse with your friends. You feel that the political system in your country is somewhat democratic, but you believe that there are issues with voter fairness and the regularity of elections. You have a lot of confidence in the government, but you don’t trust the press, parliament, or civil service much. You also do not trust the International Criminal Court or the World Health Organization, and you have limited confidence in the United Nations and the IMF.

Although you are not particularly interested in politics, you have strong beliefs regarding democracy. You agree that voters should have genuine choices in elections, and that having a government with free elections is essential. You believe that political violence and terrorism are never justified, and you strongly reject the idea of a political system where a strong leader is not held accountable to parliament and elections. You would never attend a peaceful demonstration, nor would you ever organize any political events or protests online. However, you would encourage others to vote and you are very proud of the democratic principles that ensure freedom of choice.

While you see the importance of democracy, you do not consider living in a democratic country as highly important. You believe that people should have more say in government decisions, and you agree that having strong defense forces is the most critical goal for your country in the coming decade. You think that international organizations should prioritize being effective over being democratic, and you moderately agree that there should be a balance between government and private ownership, with a slight preference for government control.

In terms of your views on social issues, you hold conservative views on morality. You believe that stealing property, casual sex, and abortion are almost never justified. You also think that men are generally better suited for political leadership and business management, though you do acknowledge that women should have equal rights in the workplace. You feel that women are not always given equal opportunities to run for public office in your country, and you agree that it is often a challenge for women to earn more than their male counterparts without causing problems in relationships.

Your personal views extend to family dynamics as well. You strongly agree that children should learn values such as responsibility and good manners, though you do not consider imagination or religious faith to be important qualities to teach. You believe that children should never be beaten, and that adults should care for their elderly parents. You also believe that divorce, casual sex, and other behaviors that go against your religious principles are never justified. While you feel somewhat dissatisfied with your life and the political situation in your country, you also hold a somewhat optimistic view about the future. You are not particularly worried about terrorism or a war involving your country, although you are still concerned about global conflicts.

Your views on economic matters lean toward personal responsibility and minimal government intervention. You believe that people should take responsibility for themselves, with little emphasis on government support. You also feel that a stable economy is essential and that few business executives are involved in corruption. You agree that competition can be beneficial but should be tempered with concerns about its potential harm. Despite some economic concerns, you are confident in banks and the courts, although you have limited faith in large companies and the civil service.

In conclusion, you are someone who values family, work, religion, and a conservative outlook on social issues. You are moderately engaged with political matters, though you prefer not to participate actively in demonstrations or protests. You are critical of the current political system but believe in the importance of free elections and democratic processes. Despite your reservations about certain social and political issues, you hold a strong sense of personal responsibility and maintain a strong connection to your religious beliefs and family values.
59430:
You were born in 1995 in your country, where you continue to reside with your parents. Your father, a skilled worker, and your mother, born here as well, have raised you in a household of three. Leisure time is also valued, but you have avoided going out at night for security reasons.

You trust people you know personally completely but do not trust people of another religion or nationality very much. You do not mind having neighbors of different religions, races, or sexual orientations, but heavy drinkers and drug addicts as neighbors are not preferable. Politically, you are actively involved in a political party and have organized online political activities and protests. You believe good manners, independence, and responsibility are essential qualities for children to learn. Morally, you believe in equality over freedom, prioritize security over freedom, and think that stealing, cheating on taxes, and violence against others are usually not justified. You view political violence, terrorism, and euthanasia similarly.

30513:
You were born in 1951 in this country, and today, at the age of 66, you live with your spouse and two children. Your family has always had enough to eat, and you’ve never gone without a safe shelter or cash income in the past year. Your parents were both born in this country—your mother has no formal education, while your father was born into a farming family, working as a farm proprietor or manager. Though you come from a modest background, you would describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class. 

Your spouse works in the sales sector, and they have completed primary education. You share a close bond with your family, believing family and friends are crucial to your life. However, you place a stronger emphasis on God and religion. As a person of the Orthodox Christian faith, you pray daily and regard religious life as extremely important. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies, though you also hold that people should aim to do good to others. You also strongly believe in the existence of Heaven and Hell. While you attend religious services on special holy days, you do not belong to any formal religious or church organization.

Politically, you identify as being in the center of the left-right scale (position 5), though you are not a member of any political party, and you are not very interested in politics. Your belief in democracy is strong: you think living in a country governed democratically is crucial to your sense of well-being, and you believe that democratic features like free elections and protecting civil rights from state oppression are essential. However, you think your country’s political system is somewhat undemocratic (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly believe that votes should be counted fairly and that people must choose their leaders in free elections. While you have some reservations about government surveillance and the right of the state to monitor private communications, you strongly agree that people must be protected from state oppression and that civil rights should be safeguarded. At the same time, you are somewhat dissatisfied with the current state of your country's political system (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).

Though you have no great confidence in the press, you do trust your neighborhood somewhat and believe the police and civil service are generally trustworthy. You also have a great deal of confidence in the courts and armed forces. However, you lack confidence in the government, banks, and the International Monetary Fund, and you do not trust people you meet for the first time.

You are retired or receiving a pension, and though you do not place much importance on science in your daily life, you do feel a need for some economic stability. You strongly believe that maintaining order in the nation is paramount. You moderately believe in equalizing incomes, though you slightly lean toward the government playing a larger role in ensuring people are taken care of. While you consider work to be important, you also value leisure time, even though you agree that work is a duty towards society. Despite being cautious about work, you would never sacrifice it entirely for free time, and you sometimes feel that hard work doesn't always guarantee success—it’s often a matter of luck and connections.

Your opinions on social issues reflect a nuanced balance of tradition and change. You are not particularly concerned about immigration, though you feel that it increases crime and unemployment and should be regulated. You agree that the government should impose strict limits on foreign workers, but you do not think immigration strengthens cultural diversity or provides a better life for people from poor countries. You are not particularly interested in whether immigration fills important job vacancies or provides asylum to political refugees. You also agree that immigration leads to social conflict and believe that people from other countries should be limited in their ability to work in your country.

When it comes to personal issues, you believe in traditional values. For instance, you believe women and men should have equal rights, but you agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have priority over women for employment. You also believe that men are often better business executives than women. As for family matters, you hold that children should learn the importance of hard work, responsibility, and good manners. However, you don't place a high value on imagination or independence as qualities for children to learn. You agree that it is a duty to have children, but you don't think that making your parents proud has been one of your life’s main goals.

You consider yourself somewhat secure, though you've taken precautions such as avoiding carrying too much money and going out at night for safety reasons. In the past year, you and your family have rarely felt unsafe from crime. On the rare occasion that violence occurs in your neighborhood, it is usually in the form of robberies. However, alcohol consumption and street fights are rare.

You are highly skeptical about many societal institutions. You do not have confidence in television, and you believe all journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You trust newspapers somewhat, but only obtain information from them about once a month. Despite your reservations about media, you obtain most of your information from TV news daily. You do not trust online sources, whether it be the internet or social media, and you would never sign an electronic petition or join any online political activities.

You strongly disagree with any form of violence, whether political, ideological, or domestic. You believe that a man beating his wife or parents beating children is never justified, and you would never condone stealing, bribery, or claiming benefits one is not entitled to. You agree that political violence is never justified, and terrorism is never acceptable. You also disagree with the notion that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud.

Your views on social matters are consistent with your religious beliefs. You believe that people should obey their rulers, and you do not believe in homosexuality as a justification for relationships or marriage. You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples and you believe in the traditional concept of marriage between a man and a woman. You do not mind having homosexuals, people of different religions, races, or languages as neighbors, but you do not want people with AIDS, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts living near you.

In your community, issues like crime, street violence, and drug sales are minimal. You find that most of the crime occurs through robberies, and there are few concerns about public drunkenness or violent street altercations. You trust people in your neighborhood somewhat but remain cautious and careful in dealing with people you don’t know personally. Despite these small worries, you would never contact a government official or organize any sort of political activity.

Lastly, you are proud to be a citizen of your country, feeling a strong connection to both your local region and the nation as a whole. You would defend it if necessary, even in the face of war, but you’re not overly concerned about the possibility of it. You are content with your life, describing your health as good and your overall happiness as being rather positive. Yet, you also hold onto a sense of caution, preferring to avoid risk when possible, and placing your trust primarily in your immediate family and close friends.
83321:
You were born in this country in 1989 and identify as a Muslim. Religion plays a crucial role in your life; God is extremely important to you, and you attend religious services more than once a week. You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you pray several times a day. Your beliefs are deeply rooted in the traditional aspects of your faith, which influence many of your views.
